  • US lawmakers were briefed by US officials that more than 75,000 Russians are estimated to either have been killed or injured in the war.
  • Talks between the Kremlin and Washington about a possible prisoner swap were said to not have come to a concrete agreement â€œyetâ€ on Thursday. The deal reportedly involves trading a notorious Russian arms dealer for a US basketball star and a former marine.
  • Estonia said on Thursday it would block Russian nationals from obtaining temporary residence permits or visas to study in Estonia, in a move its foreign minister described as putting â€œrelentless pressureâ€ on Russia and its population.
  • Former Russian state TV journalist Marina Ovsyannikova was fined 50,000 roubles ($820) after being found guilty of discrediting the countryâ€™s armed forces in social media posts condemning Russiaâ€™s actions in Ukraine.
  • Russiaâ€™s media regulator, Roskomnadzor, has filed a lawsuit to revoke the registration of the independent Novaya Gazeta newspaper, which had previously announced it would resume operations in Russia after the war had ended.

Thatâ€™s all from me, thanks for following.

Updated at 7.33pm BST

6.05pm BST

Estonia said on Thursday it would block Russian nationals from obtaining temporary residence permits or visas to study in Estonia, a move that adds to a growing list of limitations for Russian citizens.

Foreign minister Urmas Reinsalu said in a statement:

The continuation of sanctions against Russia is essential to ensuring relentless pressure on the country.

If the sanctions help in stopping Russian aggression, a positive effect on our own security will ensue.

Estonia also said short-term employment of Russian and Belarusian citizens with a legal residence permit issued by another EU member state would no longer be allowed, Agence France-Presse reports.

Reinsalu said this additional measure was aimed at ensuring that Russian and Belarusian citizens cannot bypass sanctions by obtaining a short-term visa for another country.

Belarus, a close ally of Russia, has facilitated the invasion of Ukraine by allowing Russian troops to attack from its territory.

Updated at 6.15pm BST

5.54pm BST

The Kremlin confirmed on Thursday that it is in talks with Washington on a possible prisoner swap, but said there is no concrete agreement â€œyetâ€ on a deal that reportedly involves trading a notorious Russian arms dealer for a US basketball star and a former Marine.

The US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said Washington had made a â€œsubstantial proposalâ€ to Moscow to free basketball star Brittney Griner and former Marine Paul Whelan, but declined to confirm reports that the US is offering to trade them for Russian arms trafficker Victor Bout â€“ whom my colleague Pjotr Sauer has profiled here.

In a significant development, Blinken said on Thursday he would speak to his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, â€œin the coming daysâ€ â€“ in what would be the pairâ€™s first telephone call since Moscowâ€™s invasion of Ukraine on 24 February.

Updated at 6.15pm BST

5.33pm BST

This video shows Ukrainian emergency services searching for survivors in the Donetsk region after multiple buildings were destroyed by Russian shelling, including a hotel in the town of Bakhmut under Ukrainian control.

Search and rescue operations are still under way, but the death toll from the strike on the hotel increased to four on Thursday, regional emergency services said.

Updated at 6.28pm BST

5.27pm BST

Italian anti-immigrant lparty leader Matteo Salviniâ€™s ties with Russia were again under scrutiny on Thursday following questions about the collapse of Prime Minister Mario Draghiâ€™s government.

The La Stampa newspaper reported that a diplomat at the Russian embassy met one of Salviniâ€™s aides in late May in Rome, and asked if any of the ministers from Salviniâ€™s far-right League party intended to resign from Draghiâ€™s coalition.

The meeting was said to have taken place at the same time as Salvini drew criticism for conducting parallel diplomacy with Russia over the war in Ukraine.

In 2019, Salvini described Russian president Vladimir Putin as â€œthe best statesman currently on Earthâ€, while the pro-Putin tendencies of the Italian right have been a subject of concern in other parts of the EU for some time.

The League resigned from the government coalition last week, alongside Silvio Berlusconiâ€™s Forza Italia and the populist Five Star Movement, causing Draghi to resign and triggering new elections in September.

Salvini had planned a trip to Moscow ostensibly for peace talks â€“ with flights bought by the Russian embassy, an arrangement his team insists was only done due to difficulties circumventing EU sanctions.

They said they reimbursed the embassy and the trip in the end never happened.

Foreign minister Luigi di Maio on Thursday condemned â€œthis attempt by the Russian side to have the League minister withdraw from Draghiâ€™s governmentâ€, AFP reports.

Salvini â€œmust explain the relations he has with Russiaâ€, Di Maio said, who, like Draghi is a strong supporter of western unity and support for Kyiv in response to Russiaâ€™s aggression.

Enrico Letta, leader of the centre-left Democratic party, also said the ties between Salvini and Russia were â€œconcerningâ€.

Salvini described the accusations as â€œfake newsâ€ aimed at discrediting him in the run-up to the next general election.

Updated at 5.52pm BST

4.45pm BST

At least 75,000 Russians killed or injured, US officials say

US officials estimate the number of Russian fatalities in the war has long been in the tens of thousands.

â€œWe were informed that more than 75,000 Russians were either killed or injured, which is enormous,â€ Elissa Slotkin, a Democratic House Representative who previously attended a secret US government briefing told CNN.

Dmitry Peskov, President Vladimir Putinâ€™s press secretary, rejected the figures as â€œfakeâ€ and claimed these were media reports, not US government findings.

There is no current information from the official authorities in Russia on the number of deaths, with the most recent official death toll still standing at 1,351.

The CIA recently estimated that 15,000 people had died on the Russian side.

Losses on the Ukrainian side are also unclear. Presidential adviser Oleksiy Arestovych put the losses at â€œup to 10,000â€ in early June, dpa reports.

Last week, Richard Moore, the head of MI6, said he believed the Russian invasion would begin to lose steam in coming weeks because its troops have been significantly diminished.

Updated at 5.38pm BST

4.32pm BST

At least two people were killed in the Donetsk town of Toretsk in eastern Ukraine on Thursday, when a five-story building collapsed after a Russian missile strike.

â€œToday, the rescuers of the Toretsk garrison, during emergency rescue operations on the destroyed part of a five-story residential building in the city of Toretsk, discovered and pulled out the bodies of two dead persons (one man and one woman),â€ the State Emergency Service of Ukraine said.

Updated at 4.41pm BST

4.19pm BST

Hungaryâ€™s prime minister, Viktor OrbÃ¡n, has warned Ukraine cannot win the war against Russia under Natoâ€™s current support strategy.

Speaking in Vienna after bilateral talks with the Austrian chancellor, Karl Nehammer, he said: â€œThis war in this form cannot be won,â€ adding that Natoâ€™s current strategy of supplying Ukraine with weapons and training â€œhas shown until now that it will not lead to successâ€.

Hungary has been holding up a tranche of European sanctions banning Russian oil imports into the EU by the end of the year.

OrbÃ¡n said there would not be peace without changing the strategy, adding that he feared the European Union could be â€œpushed into a war situationâ€.

â€œIt is not clear how we can avoid recession in the EU if the war carries on,â€ he said.

Updated at 4.25pm BST

3.56pm BST

Residents of Russian-occupied areas of eastern Donbas urged to evacuate

Residents of Russian-occupied areas in Ukraineâ€™s eastern Donbas region have been urged to evacuate.

Ukraineâ€™s deputy prime minister Iryna Vereshchuk said people risked being cut off from â€œpower, water, food and medical supplies, heating and communicationâ€ if they stayed in the area.

â€œBe wise and get ready for evacuations!â€ she said in a Telegram post.

The leader of pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine called on Moscow to conquer key cities across the country.

â€œToday, the time has come to liberate Russian cities, founded by Russians: Kyiv, Chernihiv, Poltava, Odesa, Dnipro, Kharkiv, Zaporizhzhia, Lutsk,â€ Denis Pushilin said on Telegram.

Updated at 4.18pm BST

3.19pm BST

The German governmentâ€™s tough stance towards Russia since the war in Ukraine began is coming under pressure at home, as worries about the resulting energy crisis and possible gas shortages intensify.

Until now, all mainstream parties from across the political spectrum had backed the strict sanctions imposed on Russia.

In recent weeks though, some German conservative leaders have voiced scepticism about the westâ€™s strategy, as opinion polls indicate that around half of the German population thinks the sanctions are hurting Germany more than Russia.

Overall however, polls show that more than two-thirds of Germans still back sanctions, Reuters reports.

About half of German households rely on gas for heating, as does approximately a third of the countryâ€™s industrial energy consumption.

Germany recorded its first monthly trade deficit since 1991 in May, partly due to inflation running atabout 8%.

Michael Kretschmer, conservative leader of the eastern Saxony region, told Die Zeit newspaper in an interview printed on Thursday:

Our entire economic system is in danger of collapsing. If we are not careful, Germany could become deindustrialised.

Concerns about government policy on Ukraine are particularly widespread in the former communist east, which has stronger ties to Moscow and stands to be more affected by the looming economic downturn as it is already worse off, Reuters reports.

Kretschmer, whose state has a population of about 4 million, is calling for the war in Ukraine to be â€œfrozenâ€ and for Europe to push for peace talks.

Kretschmer says this would boost trade of fossil fuels and grains, and prevent German economic collapse and famine in Africa, but critics fear this would legitimise Russiaâ€™s territorial gains and allow the Kremlin to regroup before further military offensives could be mounted.

Updated at 3.33pm BST

2.53pm BST

Five killed and 25 injured in Russian strike on Kropyvnytskyi

Russian missiles have struck the hangars of an aviation enterprise in Kropyvnytskyi, killing five and injuring at least 25 others, according to the head of the Kirovohrad regional administration, Andriy Raikovych. The injured include military personnel.

â€œFive people were killed as a result of missile strike that occurred in Kropyvnytskyi at 12.22pm. Another 25 people were injured, of whom 12 are military personnel and 13 civilians,â€ Raikovych said in a briefing reported by Ukrinform.

Kropyvnytskyi is to the north of Mykolaiv.

Updated at 3.02pm BST

2.34pm BST

The Belarusian opposition leader, Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, has condemned the latest escalation in the war on Ukraine launched from Belarus.

â€œHorrified to see how Russia continues to use Belarus to attack Ukraine,â€ she tweeted. â€œAt least 25 missiles were launched from Belarus targeting Kyiv, Chernihiv and other cities this morning. Lukashenka canâ€™t fool anyone. He is guilty of crimes against Belarusians and Ukrainians and must be held accountable.â€

2.18pm BST

Here are some of the latest images to be sent to us from Ukraine over the news wires.

Updated at 2.31pm BST

2.08pm BST

The British defence ministry has published a map suggesting that Ukraineâ€™s counteroffensive in the Kherson region is growing stronger, in the ministryâ€™s latest defence intelligence update on the war in Ukraine.

The UK ambassador to the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), Neil Bush, stressed in a speech in Vienna on Thursday that five months on from Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, the UK remained steadfast in its support of Ukraine.

He said:

Russia has pursued barbaric tactics, once thought consigned to history. results.webTitle: County cricket: Kemar Roach rips through Warks in Surrey win â€“ as it happened

fields.headline: County cricket: Kemar Roach rips through Warks in Surrey win â€“ as it happened
fields.trailText: Over-by-over report: Surrey remain top of Division One after beating Warwickshire, while Steve Patterson has resigned as Yorkshire captain
fields.body:
6.54pm BST

Emma John's roundup

Surrey remain top of Division One after Kemar Roach undid Warwickshireâ€™s excellent day-three batting with a devastating opening spell. He took four for 18 in five overs as the visitors were bowled out with a lead of 247. Surrey seemed to have saved all their best shots for the final chase â€“ including three sixes from Will Jacks to win the game.

Steve Patterson, whose contract will not be renewed next season, announced his resignation as Yorkshire captain after their defeat to Hampshire. An aggressive opening stand from Ian Holland and Felix Organ put Hampshire quickly on their way to their target of 214.

Tom Bailey finished with career-best figures of career 11 for 110 in Lancashireâ€™s 184-run victory against Kent, after their batters came out swinging to set up a declaration before lunch. Kent were quickly in trouble at 10 for three, and Washington Sundar contributed three for 24 with his off-spin to help wrap up the game in the afternoon.

A bold teatime declaration from Gloucestershire â€“ and 10 wickets in the match for Zafar Gohar â€“ failed to bring their first victory of the season as Northamptonshire delivered a thrilling run-chase to reach their 202-run target with two wickets remaining.

There were high-scoring draws in the Division One game at Chelmsford â€“ where Somerset racked up 605 for six declared against Essex and Tom Banton became the first concussion substitute to score a first-class century â€“ and in Durhamâ€™s Division Two game against Middlesex.

The other two matches in Division Two were over by tea. With the ball still moving at Trent Bridge, Ollie Robinson and Bradley Currie nipped out the Nottinghamshire tail early â€“ but not before they had an unassailable lead of 398. Dane Paterson and James Pattinson then picked up where they had left off on days one and two, bowling Sussex out for 142, one fewer than their first-innings total.

And Anuj Dal added a maiden first-class five-fer to his second-innings century as Derbyshire took the five remaining wickets needed to ease them to a 98-run win over Worcestershire.

Updated at 7.04pm BST

5.51pm BST

Iâ€™m currently writing up for the paper but for those still keeping an eye, Northants now need only 33 runs off the final 10 overs with five wickets in hand. Eminently doable.

5.29pm BST

A stumping for James Bracey at Gloucestershire, his second in the innings! Northants are four down now, needing 57 runs to winâ€¦ whoâ€™s your money on?

5.15pm BST

Northants have lost a third wicket in their chase against Gloucestershire. They now need 64 runs off a minimum of 19 oversâ€¦ the last live game of this round is truly, well, live.

5.11pm BST

Theyâ€™ve called time at Chester-le-Street, where Scott Borthwick and Jonathan Bushnell saw Durham through safely to the close against Middlesex after a little wobble at 57-3.

5.07pm BST

Steve Patterson says heâ€™s stepping down as Yorkshire captain in the aftermath of their loss to Hampshire:

â€œItâ€™s been made clear to me over the last few days that my career at Yorkshire will come to an end when the season finishes. With that in mind, now is the appropriate time to step back from the captaincy. It will allow me time to consider my future, and to enjoy the time I have left playing at the club.

â€œI will remain available for selection for the remainder of the summer, and if selected, will give my all for the team as I have done for the past 18 years.â€

Updated at 5.07pm BST

5.05pm BST

And itâ€™s a long-anticipated draw at Chelmsford, where the teams have shaken hands with Essex 30 for 1 in their second innings.

5.04pm BST

Thatâ€™s the game for Surreyâ€¦ Will Jacks, who came out after they lost the wickets of Ollie Pope and Ben Foakes, has just finished it with three sixes. Surrey stay top of the Championship table, with Hampshire in second.

4.59pm BST

Thereâ€™s still plenty of excitement on offer at Cheltenham, thanks to Gloucestershireâ€™s tea-time declaration with a lead of 201. Northants have knocked off more than half of those already, courtesy of Ryan Rickeltonâ€™s rollicking half-century, but Zak Chappell has just trapped him lbw on 68, Northants 115-2.

4.47pm BST

Ollie Pope has thoroughly lived up to the excited ovation he got as he walked out to the crease hereâ€¦ itâ€™s been another gem of an innings that has raced Surrey towards their target of 248, which is now only 35 away. Heâ€™s 42 off 45 balls, with Hashim Amla 75 not out at the other end.

4.39pm BST

Belated congratulations to Lancashireâ€¦

4.26pm BST

We havenâ€™t talked about Sussex yet, I realise. All out for 142, they lost their game against Notts before tea. The bowling conditions were good at Trent Bridge - witness the wickets took Ollie Robinson whenever he got his hands on the ball. James Pattinson and Dane Paterson bowled handsomely â€“ they took all 10 wickets in the first innings, and ended with eight each in the match â€“ and the ball was swinging prodigiously for them. But there were 13 single figure scores in the Sussex batting, and seven of those were ducks.

4.18pm BST

Nine down now for Kent, Nathan Gilchrist bowled for a three-ball duck. The Lancs team will be inside and enjoying a cuppa before me.

Updated at 4.18pm BST

4.16pm BST

Kent have just lost their eighth wicket against Lancashire and youâ€™d have to say the writing is on the wall at Old Trafford. After two days of swinging, seaming conditions made the ball seem unplayable, itâ€™s spin thatâ€™s doing for the batters now â€“ specifically the offspin of Indiaâ€™s Washington Sundar, which has taken 3 for 24. Daniel Bell-Drummond has been doing his best to hold Kent together, and heâ€™s still there on 69, but theyâ€™re really down to the bitter grounds at the bottom of the coffee cup here. (No, I still havenâ€™t found a coffee, and yes, I am bitter.)

4.08pm BST

Well, hereâ€™s a thing. Essex have come back after tea, and their first-innings double-centurion Nick Browne has edged the fifth ball of Peter Siddleâ€™s opening over to the keeper. So theyâ€™re 0-1, trailing Somerset by 100 runs, after a first innings in which they made 505 for 9 declared.

And instantly my mind has gone to this song by We Are Scientists:

4.05pm BST

Apologies for my absence, I have been hunting for a coffee (I still havenâ€™t found one).

3.44pm BST

Teatime-ish scores

DIVISION ONE

Chelmsford: Essex 505-9 dec v Somerset 605-6

Cheltenham: Gloucestershire 317 & 363-9 dec v Northamptonshire 479

Old Trafford: Lancashire 145 & 436-9 dec v Kent 270 & 115-7

The Oval: Warwickshire 253 & 310 v Surrey 316 & 146-2

Scarborough: Yorkshire 159 & 272 v Hampshire 218 & 214-3

DIVISION TWO

Chester-le-Street: Durham 421-7 dec & 92-3 v Middlesex 455

New Road: Derbyshire 130 & 343 v Worcestershire 185 & 190

Trent Bridge: Nottinghamshire 240 & 301 v Sussex 143 & 142

3.40pm BST

Well this is nice, 18-year-old James Rew has just scored his maiden first-class century, so he and Tom Banton can celebrate together this evening. Barkeep, another round of ice cream floats!

3.24pm BST

Itâ€™s official people, Tom Banton made history today. Remember this for your next fiendishly difficult cricket-themed quiz.

3.19pm BST

Kent are now five wickets down against Lancashire, courtesy of this piece of brilliance from Washington Sundarâ€¦

Which I think requires me to use this gif:

3.12pm BST

Hampshire beat Yorkshire at Scarborough, by seven wickets. James Vince has knocked off the final runs with a trademark cover drive, and finished on 43 not out. Itâ€™s an eighth win of the season for Hants, and a vital one for their title ambitionsâ€¦

3.04pm BST

Nottinghamshire are closing in on Sussex, who are now seven down and still 279 shy of their enormous fourth-innings target. James Pattinson has taken 3 for 43 and Cheteshwar Pujara is running out of partnersâ€¦ this game started a day after the rest, and itâ€™s likely to be one of the soonest to end.

2.58pm BST

Surrey have knocked the first 100 off their run-chase, and youâ€™d have to say theyâ€™re making it look increasingly easy. Just one wicket down, Rory Burns has brought up his 50 with a pulled four, the outfield looks quicker than it has all game â€“ and there are still 50 overs remaining to get the 139 runs needed.

2.49pm BST

Itâ€™s all over bar the seagulls at Scarborough, where Hampshire need just 26 more runs to win, and James Vince is creaming cover drives.

2.31pm BST

No hat-trick for Tom Helm at Chester-le-Street, who had Alex Lees caught at fine leg and Nic Maddinson caught behind off balls five and six of the overâ€¦ David Bedingham survived the first ball of Helmâ€™s next, and Helm bowled it out for a maiden.

But either way, Durham are really giving themselves a scare here in a game that was supposed to be heading for a bore draw. 64 for 3, with a micro-lead of 30.

Updated at 2.42pm BST

2.23pm BST

A late dash of hope for Yorkshire at Scarborough, where theyâ€™ve taken two in three balls. Holland & Organ have disbanded, Joe Weatherleyâ€™s gone for a duck, and Hampshire have flumped â€“ yes, you heard me, flumped â€“ from 135-0 to 147-3. But newcomers James Vince and Nick Gubbins now have four apiece and Hampshire only need 59 more runs to win.

Updated at 2.23pm BST

2.14pm BST

Northamptonshire have a breakthrough at Cheltenham, having failed to take a wicket all morning. The home captain Graeme van Buuren has been proving a thorn in their side as they look to finish off the Gloucestershire innings but Jack White has just had Zafar Gohar caught behind and Gloucs are now 273-7, with a lead of 111. Good thing Iâ€™m sitting in the stands with my legs up on the row in front, really.

Updated at 2.15pm BST

1.57pm BST

Heâ€™s done it! Tom Banton brings up his maiden first-class century off 104 balls, heâ€™s scored 12 fours and four sixes, and he wasnâ€™t even a part of the XI before this morning.

Holland & Organ watch: Hollandâ€™s out.

1.53pm BST

Holland & Organ have knocked another 14 off Hampshireâ€™s target already since lunch. The visitors now need just 79 runs.

Banton watch: heâ€™s on 99.

1.45pm BST

Hereâ€™s a question â€“ Tom Banton resumes after lunch at Chelmsford just seven runs off what would be a maiden first-class century. And heâ€™s only playing as a concussion substitute for Lewis Goldsworthy, who showed symptoms overnight after being beaned by a bouncer from Shane Snater. Soâ€¦ would this be the first Championship century by a concussion sub? I will endeavour to find the answer, but feel free to beat me to it.

Updated at 1.45pm BST

1.10pm BST

Lunchtime scores

DIVISION ONE

Chelmsford: Essex 505-9 dec v Somerset 480-3

Cheltenham: Gloucestershire 317 & 247-6 v Northamptonshire 479

Old Trafford: Lancashire 145 & 436-9 dec v Kent 270 & 28-3

The Oval: Warwickshire 253 & 310 v Surrey 316 & 49-0

Scarborough: Yorkshire 159 & 272 v Hampshire 218 & 121-0

DIVISION TWO

Chester-le-Street: Durham 421-7 dec & 36-0 v Middlesex 455

New Road: Derbyshire 130 & 343 v Worcestershire 185 & 190

Trent Bridge: Nottinghamshire 240 & 301 v Sussex 143 & 66-2

1.06pm BST

The PA here at the Oval just announced that thereâ€™s no ice cream truck in the ground today, and there was an audible groan from the stands. Anyway, Surrey arenâ€™t messing around here, theyâ€™ve just gone to lunch 49-0 off 13 overs and theyâ€™ve got their eyes on the prize. There are 199 runs still needed, so itâ€™s going to be a fun afternoon, Magnum or no.

12.59pm BST

Congratulations to Derbyshire, who have beaten Worcestershire at New Road before lunch! What a turnaround thatâ€™s been, from 14 for 5 on day one. The 26-year-old Anuj Dal has finished the game with a maiden five-fer (5-40) to go with his unbeaten century, so I hope heâ€™s got something nice planned for the rest of the afternoon. A celebratory ice cream at the very, very least.

12.55pm BST

Holland & Organ still plying their trade at Scarborough, theyâ€™ve scored 25 runs off the last three overs and Hampshire are now 114-0 with only 100 needed.

12.49pm BST

Watch Tom Banton go from 54 to 72 in the course of a single Dan Lawrence overâ€¦

12.45pm BST

I can only apologise for jinxing Joe Denly. The man lasted five balls after my rescue-mission line. Kent are currently 24 for 3 and I guess itâ€™s time for the back-up plan to the back-up plan. How many Thunderbirds were there, anyway?

12.38pm BST

If you havenâ€™t read mâ€™colleague Simon Burntonâ€™s report from last nightâ€™s T20, I can recommend it to you on the strength of the first line alone.

Related: Bairstow and Moeen provide fireworks as England sink South Africa in first T20

12.26pm BST

Kent have lost two at Old Trafford! Both openers gone, Zak Crawley for 4, Ben Compton for 2, and Joe Denly is going to need to launch his second rescue mission of the match here.

12.23pm BST

What a game Anuj Dal is having at New Road. Having top-scored in both innings, heâ€™s now ripping through Worcestershire with the ball â€“ heâ€™s taken three wickets in seven deliveries to bring Derbyshire to the brink of victory. Worcestershire are eight down, 117 adrift, and Dal has 4 for 32.

12.19pm BST

Bernard Cribbins has died, and while Iâ€™m too young (cough) to have appreciated his complete oeuvre, one of his songs was a big part of my childhood â€“ my gran and my parents used to sing it all the time â€“ so Iâ€™m just going to leave this here in his honour.

12.13pm BST

The first innings are finally over at Chester-le-Street where Middlesex are all out for 455 and the aggregate score is now 876 for 14. But itâ€™s still not a patch on Essex v Somerset, where 915 runs have now been scored for the loss of only 12 wickets. Congratulations to everyone involved.

12.05pm BST

The chase is on here at the Oval too. Roach has picked up his five-fer with the final wicket of the Warwickshire innings (5-72) and the teams are back out now with Surrey needing 248 in the remaining 82 overs.

12.03pm BST

Lancashire have declared against Kent, having batted in what youâ€™d call â€˜declaration styleâ€™ all morning. Theyâ€™ve added 59 runs in 12 overs and set a target of 312, with 82 overs remaining in the day. And in a funny old piece of statistical symmetry, their Nos 9, 10 and 11 all scored two runs off eight balls.

11.51am BST

Hampshire are cracking along in the chase at Scarborough. Theyâ€™re 50-0 already, 164 still to get. They seem like a reliable brand, that Holland & Organ.

11.44am BST

Kemar Roach is what we like to call â€œin the gameâ€ here at The Oval. He nearly pulled off a blinding catch at extra cover, parrying the ball as it whipped over his head. Roach wheeled around, knocked it up again, and seemed about to take it on the dive â€“ you have to picture this all happening in the beat of a hummingbirdâ€™s wing â€“ before he, and the ball, both hit the ground. It would have been the kind of catch they write ballads about.

But anyway, he didnâ€™t make it, so instead he just knocked Nathan McAndrewâ€™s off stump out of the ground in the next over.

Updated at 11.45am BST

11.34am BST

Nottinghamshire are all out at Trent Bridge, so Sussex now have a fourth-innings target. Unfortunately for them, itâ€™s 399. But excellent tail-mopping work there from Ollie Robinson, whoâ€™s taken two in four balls to finish with a five-fer. His figures from this match are 9 for 104.

11.28am BST

And another one! Brad Wheal lbw to Jordan Clark for 1. Warwickshire were 270-4 overnight, theyâ€™re now 293-8.

11.25am BST

Two more wickets at The Oval! Kemar Roach now has three in six deliveriesâ€¦ Sam Hain fell for 96 to a tumbling catch from Ben Foakes and now Michael Burgess is trapped lbw. This is a terrible start for Warwickshire after all the hard work they put in yesterday.

11.19am BST

A good (and dare we say vital?) start to the day for Sussex, who have taken two wickets already at Trent Bridge. And how pleasing is this one? Itâ€™s the cricketing equivalent of ASMR.

11.14am BST

Hampshireâ€™s opening pair, Holland and Organ, sound like a firm that makes high-end audio equipment, I reckon. Anyway, theyâ€™re 10-0 as they set about chasing that target of 214 from Yorkshire at Scarborough.

Kemar Roach has just got Will Rhodes out here at the Oval, for 74 â€“ Warwickshire now five down. The batting has felt, shall we say, languid, at points here over the past couple of days but Sam Hain is now only five away from his century and he and Michael Burgess need to up this lead of 217. And even as I write that, Burgess gets off the mark with a four!

11.01am BST

Iâ€™ve just spotted that comments werenâ€™t turned on on the blog this morning so apologies for that, they should be switched on now.

10.58am BST

Ollie Robinson â€“ the Kent Covid-sub, not the Sussex and England seamer â€“ is feeling confident that batting is getting easier at Old Trafford, where Lancashire are currently 252 runs ahead with five wickets remaining. â€œI guess it will be a different challenge when it comes to batting but itâ€™s a pretty good pitch to bat on now,â€ he said last night. â€œWe have batted to save games quite a lot this season and actually done it quite well and although obviously we want to win I think a draw is the most likely outcome.â€

10.50am BST

Weâ€™ve got a delayed start at Chester-le-Street, where itâ€™s been a bit damp, and the covers are only just coming off. Play at 11.15am there.

10.49am BST

Start of play scores

DIVISION ONE

Chelmsford: Essex 505-9 dec v Somerset 359-3

Cheltenham: Gloucestershire 317 & 135-5 v Northamptonshire 479

Old Trafford: Lancashire 145 & 377-5 v Kent 270

The Oval: Warwickshire 253 & 270-4 v Surrey 316

Scarborough: Yorkshire 159 & 272 v Hampshire 218 & 9-0

DIVISION TWO

Chester-le-Street: Durham 421-7 dec v Middlesex 417-7

New Road: Derbyshire 130 & 343 v Worcestershire 185 & 108-5

Trent Bridge: Nottinghamshire 240 & 284-7 v Sussex 143

10.37am BST

Wednesday's round up

Yorkshire, Lancashire and Derbyshire can all congratulate themselves on their fighting spirit at the end of this third dayâ€™s play. In each case their batters dragged them back into games that they had seemed almost to forfeit with their low scores on the very first day.

In Division One, Lancashire vastly improved on their first-innings total of 145 against Kent thanks to Luke Wells, who fell two runs short of his hundred, and 25-year-old Josh Bohannon, who made his sixth first-class century. Lancashire finished the day on 377 for five, with a lead of 252.

Hampshire rued a dropped catch off Adam Lyth as he began Yorkshireâ€™s reply with a steady half-century, before Jonathan Tattersall (63) and Matthew Waite (47) helped the home side set a target of 214.

Gloucestershire had less luck against Northamptonshire, who added an extra 126 to their overnight score from their final three wickets. Only Marcus Harris provided the kind of score Gloucestershire needed and at 135 for five, they still trail by 27 runs.

Warwickshire had a good day against Surrey despite losing early wickets. They recovered from seven for two to 270 for four, Sam Hain and Will Rhodes ending the day with an unbroken partnership of 127, Warwickshireâ€™s lead 207.

Somerset saved the follow-on against Essexâ€™s 505 for nine declared, although the joy of Matt Renshawâ€™s century was tempered by concern for captain Tom Abell, who retired hurt on 90. Somerset will resume on 359 for 3.

In Division Two Middlesex kept their heads and compiled a patient response to Durhamâ€™s 421 for seven declared. Anuj Dal finished with unbeaten century as Derbyshire continued to pile on runs against Worcestershire, setting them a fourth innings target of 289. And on the second day at Trent Bridge, three quick wickets from Ollie Robinson could not stop Nottinghamshire racking up a 381-run lead against Sussex.

10.23am BST

Preamble

Hello from The Oval, where the Warwickshire players are engaged in a fairly noisy game of foot-volleyball on the outfield. Meanwhile the gentlemen of Surrey are standing in a circular huddle, arms clasped behind their backs, overlooked by the Micky Stewart Membersâ€™ Pavilion. The big question here is, when will Warwickshire declare? (And what are the rules of foot-volleyball? Iâ€™d be delighted to hear your answers to that one, and whether thereâ€™s a better name for it.)

results.webTitle: Taxpayers left with Â£421m bill after one in 12 firms default on Covid loans

fields.headline: Taxpayers left with Â£421m bill after one in 12 firms default on Covid loans
fields.trailText: About 8% of borrowers â€“ 130,000 firms â€“ have so far failed to repay government-backed emergency loans
fields.body:
Taxpayers have been left to foot a Â£421m bill to cover soured Covid debts, after one in 12 businesses defaulted on state-backed emergency loans distributed at the height of the pandemic, official figures reveal.

In the first set of figures detailing the performance of government-backed loans offered to struggling firms during the outbreak, the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said about 8% of 1.6m borrowers â€“ roughly 130,000 â€“ failed to repay their debts as of March this year.

Related: Digital bank Starling reports first profit on back of strong loan book

The bulk of the claims â€“ around Â£352m â€“ were made for bounce back loans, the popular scheme which accounted for Â£47bn of the Â£77bn total lent to businesses through the programme.

High street banks and online lenders, which distributed the loans on behalf of the government, subsequently claimed a combined Â£421m of taxpayer cash to cover the defaults.

About 18,000 of the 1.5m bounce back loans claimed were flagged for suspected fraud by lenders, though no updated estimates were provided on the potential cost to the government. It has previously been estimated that fraud losses could top Â£4.9bn, though more recent estimates from PwC, the accountancy firm hired by the government, reduced that figure to Â£3.5bn.

â€œWe are still early in the life of the schemes and in the lending cycle, so it is too soon to accurately assess levels of fraud and credit losses,â€ the business department said.

Defaults and fraud estimates, which are collected by the British Business Bank, are expected to change as more debts become due, with many firms having taken advantage of a programme allowing them to extend their loans over 10 years.

Bounce back loans, which were 100% government backed, were distributed by 28 high street banks and other lenders, with applicants able to borrow up to Â£50,000 each.

Launched in May 2020, the scheme was one of former chancellor, and now Tory leadership candidate, Rishi Sunakâ€™s biggest interventions during the first months of the pandemic, as he attempted to safeguard the economy.

However, critics have claimed that not enough attention was paid to potential fraud, as customers were allowed to self-certify that they met certain criteria in an effort to get more money out the door.

Those concerns eventually led to the resignation of the anti-fraud minister Theodore Agnew in January, who cited the governmentâ€™s â€œwoefulâ€ efforts to control fraud, and he has since warned banks to be â€œvery carefulâ€ before claiming the government guarantee.

Lord Agnew later entered into a battle with digital Starling Bank, after raising questions around its fraud controls, claims the bank has denied. Starling has asked Agnew to withdraw his statement.

Metro Bank, Barclays and Starling Bank have claimed the most money to date on bounce back loans, with the government paying out Â£122m, Â£88m and Â£61m respectively.

However, the proportion of claims relative to their total loans varied, with Metro having claimed an estimated 8.5% of the total, while the amount claimed by Barclays and Starling totalled an estimated 0.8% and 3.8%, respectively.

All three lenders said they were dedicating significant resources to try to recover funds before claiming the state guarantee.

Two lenders â€“ Tide and Capital on Tap â€“ claimed back about a quarter of the total money they each lent to businesses through the bounce back scheme.

Tide said it conducted all appropriate checks and that it was quicker to put in claims than some of its peers. It also said that some of its customers were â€œyoungerâ€ and therefore at higher risk of failure. Tide added that the next 12 months would offer a â€œbetter pictureâ€ of defaults across all lenders.

The government also warned against reading too far into the lender-by-lender data, saying some â€œmay be more advanced than othersâ€ in submitting claims, â€œwhich could lead to figures being distortedâ€.

Capital on Tap did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

results.webTitle: Terry Neill, former Arsenal and Tottenham manager, dies aged 80

fields.headline: Terry Neill, former Arsenal and Tottenham manager, dies aged 80
fields.trailText: Terry Neill, who led Arsenal to three consecutive FA Cup finals from 1978-80, has died aged 80
fields.body:
The former Arsenal and Tottenham manager Terry Neill has died aged 80. Neill led Arsenal to three consecutive FA Cup finals from 1978-80, winning one, and to the 1980 Cup Winnersâ€™ Cup final.

Neill played for Arsenal, Hull and Northern Ireland as a defender, joining Hull as player-manager in 1970 at the age of 28. He left Hull to succeed Bill Nicholson at Tottenham in 1974 and was recruited by Arsenal two years later.

He stayed there until his sacking in December 1983 and never managed again even though he was then only 41.

The 1979 FA Cup final win over Manchester United in a dramatic game settled by Alan Sunderlandâ€™s late winner provided Neillâ€™s only trophy, the victory sandwiched by Cup final defeats against Ipswich and West Ham.

Arsenal reached the 1980 Cup Winnersâ€™ Cup final against Valencia by beating Juventus but lost on penalties after misses by Liam Brady and Graham Rix. The clubâ€™s highest league finish under Neill was third in 1981, one of four top-six finishes.

Neill had spent more than 10 years as a player at Arsenal after joining from Bangor City for Â£2,500 in December 1959. He played 275 games for the club and at 20 became the youngest captain in their history, later returning as their youngest-ever manager. He played 59 times for Northern Ireland and had a spell as their part-time manager.

Arsenal said: â€œTerry Neillâ€™s status as both club captain and manager made him a major influence on 20th-century Arsenal. His fantastic contribution â€“ and indeed his character â€“ will always be appreciated by everyone associated with the club.â€

Tottenham narrowly avoided relegation in Neillâ€™s first season there but he led them to ninth a year later.

results.webTitle: â€˜An insultâ€™: huge profits at Shell and Centrica cause outrage amid soaring energy bills

fields.headline: â€˜Insult to millionsâ€™: Shell and Centrica profits cause outrage as energy bills soar
fields.trailText: News of billion-pound profits comes after UK households warned average annual bill could hit Â£3,850 by 2023
fields.body:
Soaring profits at two of the UKâ€™s biggest energy companies have been described as an â€œinsultâ€ to millions of people struggling amid the cost of living crisis, with high oil and gas prices funding multibillion-pound rewards for their shareholders.

A day after households were warned average annual energy bills could hit Â£3,850 from January, triple the level at the beginning of this year, Shell and Centrica sparked outrage by announcing huge windfalls.

Shell posted record earnings of $11.4bn (nearly Â£10bn) for the three-month period from April to June and promised to give shareholders payouts worth Â£6.5bn.

Asked about the stark contrast with punishingly high bills faced by households already struggling amid sky-high inflation, Shellâ€™s chief executive, Ben van Beurden, said the company could not â€œperform miraclesâ€ to bring oil and gas prices down, adding: â€œIt is what it is.â€

At the same time, Centrica, the owner of British Gas, reinstated its dividend, handing investors Â£59m, after reporting operating profits of Â£1.3bn during the first half of 2022.

Frances Oâ€™Grady, the general secretary of the Trades Union Congress, said: â€œThese eye-watering profits are an insult to the millions of working people struggling to get by because of soaring energy bills.

â€œWorking people are facing the longest and harshest wage squeeze in modern history. Itâ€™s time working people got their fair share of the wealth they create, starting with real action to bring bills down.â€

Debt advice charities, businesses and MPs redoubled their calls on ministers to take action now to avoid plunging millions more housholds into financial distress, as concern mounted at the lack of a coherent government plan.

The energy regulator, Ofgem, is due to announce a hike in the energy price cap within days. It will take effect from October, with another increase expected in January. According to forecasts issued earlier this week, unless the flow of Russian gas into Europe increases, average dual-fuel tariffs could soar to Â£3,850 a year from January.

If the prediction proves correct, average bills will have risen more than Â£2,500 within a year.

The war in Ukraine, combined with bottlenecks caused by pandemic lockdowns, has led to a surge in oil and gas prices, causing misery for motorists and households as the prices charged for gas, electricity and petrol have reached all-time highs.

Ed Miliband, the shadow secretary for climate change and net zero, accused the government of being â€œasleep at the wheelâ€, amid a Tory leadership contest that is pitting the former chancellor Rishi Sunak against the foreign secretary, Liz Truss.

â€œAs profits soar to record levels for oil and gas producers, we face a serious and worsening energy bills crisis, far worse even than a couple of months ago,â€ Miliband said.

He said both Truss and Sunak were â€œliving on another planetâ€ when it came to the â€œcost of living emergencyâ€. In May, the government announced a Â£400 rebate on bills, which comes into effect in October and will be paid over six months.

But gas prices have since risen further, after Russia dramatically reduced the volume of gas it sends to Europe through its largest pipeline earlier this month.

The Â£400 rebate was only â€œscratching the surfaceâ€, according to experts at the energy analysis firm Cornwall Insight, which has warned that bills of more than Â£3,500 â€“ or Â£300 a month â€“ will last â€œwell into 2024â€. The debt charity the Money Advice Trust said the sum was â€œunlikely to provide much respiteâ€.

Eight million vulnerable households are also entitled to separate support from a Â£15bn cost-of-living package, worth up to Â£1,200 each.

Labour has yet to come up with a comprehensive policy to tackle exorbitant bills. It has called on the government to scrap the 5% VAT rate on household energy, but this would only deliver further savings of Â£98 a year based on the current price cap, which is set at Â£1,971.

During the Tory leadership campaign, Sunak has also come out in favour of pausing these VAT charges, something he opposed when he had the power to implement it as chancellor.

Truss, who has said she would impose a moratorium on green levies added to bills, said on Thursday that she opposed windfall taxes on energy firms.

Miliband said Truss â€œappears to believe that the cost of living crisis can be solved by abandoning renewable energy â€“ the cheapest form of power we have. The government is asleep at the wheel.â€

Speaking after he unveiled Shellâ€™s record quarterly profits, Van Beurden said oil companies were aware of the difficulties that ordinary people faced. â€œBut we cannot perform miracles either,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m very mindful that that is a difficult message to hear, but it is what it is.â€

More than 8m households â€“ one in three in the UK â€“ will fall into fuel poverty after Octoberâ€™s price cap rise, according to National Energy Action. Fuel poverty is defined as spending more than 10% of household income on energy.

The Conservative MP Alec Shelbrooke told PoliticsHome on Thursday he had seen â€œabsolute fearâ€ in the eyes of his constituents and was â€œnot sureâ€ how his own family would pay their bills.

On Thursday, the UKâ€™s three leading debt charities â€“ Citizens Advice, the Money Advice Trust and StepChange â€“ called on Ofgem to improve protections for consumers who owe money to their energy supplier, including cracking down on â€œharmfulâ€ debt collection practices.

Joanna Elson, the head of the Money Advice Trust, which runs National Debtline and Business Debtline, said: â€œFurther targeted support is needed for the many people already unable to afford their energy bills and for those on the lowest incomes, including significantly raising benefits.â€

An Ofgem spokesperson said: â€œProtecting consumers during these very difficult times is our top priority and we are doing all we can to hold suppliers to account on supporting their customers.

â€œRecently we reviewed all suppliers to make sure they were charging direct debits fairly, have told them to review the highest increases and asked some to make immediate improvements in how they handle them.â€

Earlier this week, MPs on the business and energy select committee called for the energy price cap, introduced in 2019 in an effort to combat profiteering, to be replaced by a â€œsocial tariffâ€. This would involve the poorest households receiving discounted energy, with the cost funded either through taxation or spread between more well-off bill payers.

The MPs said millions of people would be plunged into unmanageable debt without further government help.

The Treasury said its windfall tax on energy profits, announced by Sunak earlier this year, would raise about Â£5bn in its first year to â€œhelp pay for support for millions of the most vulnerable householdsâ€.

A spokesperson for the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said: â€œWe understand that global inflationary pressures are squeezing household finances, which is why the government has introduced an extraordinary Â£37bn package to help households, including Â£1200 each for 8m of the most vulnerable households.â€

results.webTitle: Sunakâ€™s vow to stop housebuilding on green belt labelled as â€˜desperateâ€™

fields.headline: Sunakâ€™s vow to stop housebuilding on green belt labelled as â€˜desperateâ€™
fields.trailText: Experts warned the move would significantly worsen the UKâ€™s housing crisis and push up living costs
fields.body:
Rishi Sunakâ€™s vow to block housebuilding on the green belt has been labelled a â€œdesperateâ€ bid for Tory membersâ€™ votes, with experts warning that the move would significantly worsen the UKâ€™s housing crisis and push up living costs.

With just days until ballots drop in the leadership contest to replace Boris Johnson, and behind Liz Truss in the polls, Sunak said new property development should take place squarely on â€œbrownfield, brownfield, brownfieldâ€.

His pledge to the partyâ€™s grassroots was that a blanket rejection would be issued for councils that ask to change green belt boundaries in order to release land for housing.

Related: Houses for â€˜ghostsâ€™: ONS overestimated growth in many areas, census suggests

Sunakâ€™s campaign contrasted the announcement with rival Truss, who in May 2019 as chief secretary to the Treasury suggested 1m homes should be built on the London green belt and around other â€œgrowing citiesâ€ to help more under-40s buy their first property.

The green belt â€“ covering 12.4% of England, according to the governmentâ€™s latest figures â€“ was labelled â€œextremely preciousâ€ by the former chancellor, who accused councils of â€œcircumventing the views of residentsâ€.

He claimed more homes could be built while protecting â€œour most precious landscapeâ€ with space for 1m homes across brownfield sites â€“ particularly in north-west England, the West Midlands and Yorkshire.

The Richmond MP, who was reportedly granted planning permission last year to extend his North Yorkshire home on to agricultural land to make space for a pool, gym and tennis court, said â€œinner-city densificationâ€ would also be key to increasing housing stock.

Since 2006, the green belt has shrunk by about 1%, according to analysis by the House of Commons library. Sunakâ€™s team vowed to stop councils appealing to the Planning Inspectorate to declassify patches of green belt land by updating their local plans. He pledged to end this practice by updating the National Planning Policy Framework, and scrapping the possibility of â€œinappropriateâ€ development on the green belt â€œin very special circumstancesâ€.

The promise drew ire from Robert Colvile, who helped co-author the December 2019 Conservative manifesto and runs the Centre for Policy Studies thinktank set up by Margaret Thatcher. He said Sunakâ€™s and Trussâ€™s housing plans â€œpander to the fantasy that we can build all the houses we need on brownfield far away from where any Tory voters might see itâ€.

The green belt has reduced by only 194 sq km since 2014 and at current rates it would take a millennium to be covered, according to Colvile. He added: â€œBritain has a housing crisis. It is crippling our economy. It is blighting the lives of a generation. Yet more nimbyism is emphatically not the answer.â€

Other libertarian thinktanks condemned the move. The Institute for Economic Affairs said it would â€œflush aspiration down the drainâ€ and that planning restrictions â€œsignificantly push up the cost of living, while making homeownership unattainable, forcing people into lower-paying jobs and increasing commute times and pollutionâ€. The Adam Smith Institute also said building homes where people want to live and work was â€œvital if we want to turbo-charge growth and reduce the cost of livingâ€.

Giles Wilkes, a former special adviser to Theresa May, called it a â€œpretty desperate and regressive moveâ€.

The Conservative leader of Swindon council, David Renard, opposed Sunakâ€™s move. He said: â€œThere is a consensus that the country needs to build 300,000 homes per year and that we are currently short of building those numbers.

â€œAny centrally imposed numbers or locations on each local authority are not welcome as it is for councils to determine what the housing need is in their areas and to decide where best to locate those new homes.â€

However, Johnsonâ€™s proposed planning reforms that threatened green belt were â€œclearly a key factor in the loss of Chesham and Amersham to the Lib Demsâ€ in June 2021, said Martin Tett, Tory leader of Buckinghamshire council, who added that Sunakâ€™s pledge would be â€œvery welcome to local membersâ€.

CPRE, the countryside charity, calculated that more than 250,000 homes are currently proposed to be built on land removed from the green belt â€“ more than four times as many as in 2013 â€“ and said â€œpiece by piece, local authorities are eating into protected countryside, using blunt, numerical targets that fail to deliver affordable and social housingâ€.

Tom Fyans, its director of campaigns and policy, said: â€œApplications to change green belt boundaries in order to release land for housing have soared since 2013. This is despite the pressing need to revitalise our countryside so that it can suck up carbon, boost wildlife and provide much-needed space for recreation in nature. We wholeheartedly welcome Sunakâ€™s brownfield-first approach to planning.â€

results.webTitle: NSW issued 501 fines to children under 15 in past year for not wearing or carrying mask

fields.headline: NSW issued 501 fines to children under 15 in past year for not wearing or carrying mask
fields.trailText: Redfern Legal Centre says $20,000 in fines issued is â€˜unjustâ€™ and â€˜sets children up for failureâ€™
fields.body:
About 500 children aged under 15 were fined a total of $20,000 for not wearing or carrying a mask in New South Wales in the past 12 months, including 34 who remain in an unpaid work and development scheme to reduce their debts.

The state government has faced sustained criticism for its pursuit of children over Covid rule breaches, particularly given the confusing and shifting nature of public health orders and the disproportionate impact Covid fines are having on the most disadvantaged.

Related: The Covid fines that should never have been issued

Figures obtained by the Redfern Legal Centre show the state issued 493 fines to children aged 15 or under for failing to wear a mask, worth a total of $19,720, in the past financial year.

About 84 of those had been paid and 390 remained outstanding as of 8 July. More up-to-date figures provided by the government late on Thursday showed 501 fines were issued in the financial year, 147 of which had been paid, and 295 of which had been withdrawn or waived.

An alliance of community legal centres have repeatedly urged the NSW government to replace fines issued to children with cautions. They have warned the fines are significantly affecting vulnerable children, who have neither the capacity to pay or understand the enforcement system.

The NSW government has refused the request, instead suggesting that children could be placed on work and development orders (WDOs) â€“ a scheme allowing individuals to use unpaid work, education, courses, or counselling to reduce their fines.

The suggestion, made in private correspondence revealed by the Guardian, prompted an angry response from community legal centres, who say fines for Covid breaches should not have been issued to children in the first place.

Revenue NSW confirmed late on Thursday that WDOs were being used for children fined for mask offences.

It said 34 of the 501 fines issued to children for the offence were still outstanding. All 34 were being paid off using a WDO, which Revenue NSW argues is a voluntary process designed to aid those without the financial means to pay back fines.

Of the 147 fines that had been paid back in full, 44 had been fully paid via a WDO. The rest were resolved via normal payment.

No fines have been issued to children under the age of 13.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

Redfern Legal Centre senior solicitor Samantha Lee said the pandemic had shown the stateâ€™s fine enforcement system was â€œunduly harshâ€ on children.

â€œA warning or caution should be a first port of call for any child alleged to have committed a summary offence,â€ Lee said. â€œThe NSW fine system basically treats children the same way as adults, which is unjust and sets children up for failure.â€

Lee said the legal centreâ€™s casework on Covid fines, which includes a NSW supreme court challenge to the legality of fines in three test cases, showed that many of the penalties were not issued according to law. That is because the â€œlaw was rapidly changing and no one, not even police, were able to keep up with the lawâ€, she said.

Related: NSW government suggested children as young as 10 could work off $1,000 Covid fines

â€œWe also know the majority of fines were issued to those from low socioeconomic areas,â€ Lee said. â€œIt was a hard and confusing time for children to live through. Itâ€™s time for the government to show compassion and withdraw these fines.â€

Revenue NSW said it was committed to striking the right balance between â€œhelping resolve fines and ensuring hardship is not experienced by customersâ€.

Fines were reviewed by a senior police officer before being referred to Revenue NSW, a spokesperson said, and young people had the ability to request their fines be reviewed.

â€œRevenue NSW considers withdrawing or cautioning fines on a case-by-case basis, having regard to the Public Health Order at the time and may do so in consultation with issuing authorities,â€ the spokesperson said. â€œRevenue NSW cannot comment on decisions made by issuing authorities.â€

A total of 3,840 fines had been issued to children or teenagers under 18, and 91% of them had been resolved in some way. About 8% were subject to WDOs.

The Aboriginal Legal Service has also warned of the significant impact Covid fine enforcement was having on Indigenous communities. Indigenous Australians were having their licences suspended for non-payment, the ALS said, including young people who were left unable to obtain their learner licences.

results.webTitle: The Guardian view on nuclear warfare: dialogue or destruction | Editorial

fields.headline: The Guardian view on nuclear warfare: dialogue or destruction
fields.trailText: Editorial: Britainâ€™s national security adviser has thoughtful words about contacts with Russia and China. His bosses need to listen
fields.body:
When the most senior figure in Britainâ€™s defence and security establishment warns of the increased risk of accidental nuclear war, the rest of us should pay attention. Even today, when security chiefs speak more often in public than they once did, they still ration their pronouncements. So when the UKâ€™s national security adviser, Sir Stephen Lovegrove, speaks in Washington about a breakdown in communications with Russia and China causing an enhanced risk of â€œrapid escalation to strategic conflictâ€, as he did this week, those words should be taken very seriously indeed.

The increased international danger is starkly obvious. Russiaâ€™s deliberate invasion of Ukraine, its use there of hypersonic Kinzhal weapons and its threats of further escalation involving its nuclear arsenal add up to the most destabilising repertoire of state-on-state aggression in modern Europe since 1945. In Asia, Chinaâ€™s increasingly bellicose postures over Taiwan and in the South China Sea, its intensive nuclear missile development programmes and its disdain towards arms control agreements raise the stakes much higher. Iran and North Korea, where Kim Jong-un appears to be preparing the countryâ€™s first nuclear test for five years, add further to the current volatility.

Sir Stephen warned that what is happening is not a return to the nuclear tensions of the cold war. In those days, he argued, Nato and the Soviet Union by and large understood one anotherâ€™s military doctrines of deterrence, containment and the avoidance of first nuclear weapon use. That is not the case today. Nuclear doctrine is opaque, and possibly different, in Moscow and Beijing, never mind in Pyongyang. The conditions for instability are therefore greater, either through deliberate acts or miscalculations. Although Sir Stephen did not say so, this environment could trigger a flawed and fateful western response, not just an act of aggression by one of the westâ€™s adversaries.

Western faith in dialogue with hostile rivals has been massively damaged by the Russian invasion of Ukraine. A similar confrontation with China over Taiwan would shatter confidence still further. But Sir Stephen is right to say that all sides must continue to look for ways of conducting dialogue. Some foundations are better than none at all. For that reason alone, it is helpful that Joe Biden and Xi Jinping were holding their first conversation in many months on Thursday. The expected start of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference in New York next week is potentially another confidence-building development in a crucial area. In spite of all the obvious difficulties, arms control remains an indispensable means of tackling the current volatility.

The key role in the west will continue to be played by the United States. But Britain is not currently doing its bit. Boris Johnson prefers to grandstand as a fancy dress war leader. Liz Truss is doing a Margaret Thatcher tribute act in the hope of becoming his successor. Rishi Sunak is afraid of saying anything for fear of the Tory right. This week, though, the Commons defence committee accused the government of being â€œarrogant and unwilling to learn the lessonsâ€ of its defence errors, including in Ukraine, while an Institute for Government report describes the Foreign Office as understaffed, with low morale and expertise on Russia continuing to be downgraded. Sir Stephen Lovegroveâ€™s Washington speech may be a welcome piece of strategic thinking at the heart of government. But the people who most need to get his message are the British ministers for whom he works.

Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a letter of up to 300 words to be considered for publication, email it to us at guardian.letters@theguardian.com

results.webTitle: Independents, diversity and climate: highlights of new MPsâ€™ first speeches to Australian parliament

fields.headline: Independents, diversity and climate: highlights of new MPsâ€™ first speeches to Australian parliament
fields.trailText: As Australiaâ€™s most diverse federal parliament opened, new members introduced themselves and set out priorities
fields.body:
The 47th parliament is the most diverse ever, including a record number of women, 11 First Nations representatives and a lower house crossbench of 16 independent or minor party MPs.

Related: Australian parliament 101: your questions about key words and processes, answered

But before any of the new MPs can speak on important bills or other parliamentary business, the first order of business is a speech to introduce yourself and set out priorities.

Here are the highlights from the maiden speeches of the opening week of the 47th parliament.

Independents dig boot into party system

Campaign themes of climate, integrity and women featured heavily in the first speeches of new independent MPs â€“ often held together by the idea that local representation trumps party politics in delivering for constituents.

The MP for Goldstein, Zoe Daniel, said her fatherâ€™s experience as a state Labor candidate in Tasmania â€œput [her] off party politics for lifeâ€, describing it as â€œa murky mess of factionalism and dark political tacticsâ€.

Wearing purple and white, the colours of suffragists like Vida Goldstein after whom her electorate is named, Daniel noted that Goldstein had rejected party politics, describing it in the early 20th century as â€œa system that is entirely out of date â€¦ [and] a cumbersome, unbusinesslike method of running the countryâ€.

Daniel, a former ABC reporter, spoke about her personal experience of â€œclimate-related disastersâ€ including â€œthe scenes in Tacloban [in the Philippines], flattened by a storm surge that destroyed 90% of the city â€¦ bodies in the streets, cars in trees, giant boats atop buildings â€¦ and, amid the rubble, the shattered lives of residentsâ€.

This, she said, was â€œa turning point for me, a realisation of the impact climate change and its increasingly unmanageable weather events would have on communitiesâ€.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

The MP for North Sydney, Kylea Tink, said it was â€œnotableâ€ that â€œnowhere in [the constitution] was there any use of the word â€˜partyâ€™â€.

Tink called for more compassion towards refugees:

We have already heard much talk about the extraordinary gift that is Australiaâ€™s multicultural reality and of the courage it takes to run with your family from imminent threat. I would challenge us as a parliament to strive to truly do better in the area of human rights. True refugees deserve our compassion, not our disdain.â€

The MP for Kooyong, Monique Ryan, was gracious to her predecessor, the former treasurer Josh Frydenberg, describing him as a â€œwell-respected member of this placeâ€.

But she also delivered a sensational backhander about the choice the electors of Kooyong made:

Kooyong has always been a seat held by conservative politicians â€“ since it was formed in 1944, the Liberal party has always held Kooyong. The last time an incumbent lost his seat in Kooyong was 1922 â€“ proof positive, Mr Speaker, that not all once-in-a-century events are bad.â€

The MP for Curtin, Kate Chaney, whose grandfather was a member of the Menzies government and whose uncle, Fred Chaney, was deputy to Malcolm Fraser, said she â€œnever felt a pull towards either political party, feeling stranded in the middleâ€.

Chaney said:

But I feel a pull when I read the words of Menzies who said he looked forward to â€¦ â€˜a better distribution of wealth, to a keener sense of social justice and social responsibilityâ€™. I wonder if that might have been a party I would have been willing to join.

Labor MPs rally for diversity and climate

On Tuesday the first government MPs to give speeches were Sally Sitou, the member for Reid in Sydneyâ€™s inner west, and Zaneta Mascarenhas, the member for Swan in inner south Perth.

Sitou, a Chinese-Lao-Australian, praised the multicultural makeup of parliament and sent a message to young Australians:

You are not defined by your postcode, the school you went to, or where your parents came from. In this country, you are defined by the content of your character and what you want to do for others â€“ where the potential and promise of our nation is only limited by our imagination.â€

Mascarenhas noted her â€œAustralian story would not be possibleâ€ if not for a Labor government:

When my parents went to the embassy in Kenya they said to my dad, â€˜you have the right skills but youâ€™re the wrong colourâ€™. This is because the White Australia policy was still in place. My parents came to Australia after Gough Whitlam dismantled the last parts of the White Australia policy. This story taught me two things â€“ politics is personal â€¦ and that politics can transform lives.â€

Laborâ€™s Fatima Payman, a daughter of a refugee born in Afghanistan, spoke about being the first hijab-wearing Muslim senator.

Payman:

A hundred years ago, let alone 10 years ago, would this parliament have been as accepting? A hundred years ago, let alone 10 years ago, would this parliament accept a woman choosing a hijab to be elected? I will have more to say about this in my first speech in September, but, for those who choose to advise me about what I should wear or judge my competency based on my external experience, know that the hijab is my choice. I want young girls who decide to wear the hijab to do it with pride and to do it with the knowledge that they have the right to wear it. I wonâ€™t judge someone wearing boardies and flip-flops across the street. I donâ€™t expect people to judge me for wearing my scarf.

The MPs also had a message on climate.

Sitou argued â€œit is time to be audacious dreamers and imagine a better wayâ€. â€œSurely we cannot say to my son and his generation that what we are doing to address climate change is enough.â€

Mascarenhas, an engineer who helped major corporations decarbonise, warned that while some in the resource sector were doing the right thing â€œthis is not uniformâ€.

â€œSmart companies are looking at their climate risks and opportunities over the next three decades,â€ she said. â€œThis includes looking at value chains and scope 3 emissions. For us to achieve our goal of well below 2C of warming, we need all sectors of the economy to pull their weight.â€

Jacinta Price lobbies against Indigenous Voice

The Country Liberal senator Jacinta Price, who described herself as â€œan empowered Warlpiri Celtic Australian womanâ€, spoke about the many â€œacts of symbolismâ€ extended to demonstrate â€œwe are not racist but are overwhelmingly in support of Aboriginal Australiaâ€, from the reconciliation walk across the Sydney harbour bridge to the welcome to country.

Price said:

I personally have had more than my fill of being symbolically recognised. It has become a racial stereotype that we Australians of Indigenous heritage should belong to and support the Labor party. It was an exchange with the former leader of the Labor party Bill Hayden, who conveyed this very stereotype, that compelled Neville Bonner to confirm his membership within the Liberal party of Australia. Bonner had been handing out how-to-vote cards for a Liberal friend when Hayden exclaimed, â€˜What are you doing handing out those how-to-vote cards? We do more for you bloody Aborigines than those bastards do.â€™ â€˜Well,â€™ Bonner thought, â€˜how dare someone come up to me and presume that, because Iâ€™m black, I should support a particular party!â€™

It is the same attitude we hear with platitudes of motherhood statements from our now prime minister, who suggests, without any evidence whatsoever, that a voice to parliament bestowed upon us through the virtuous act of symbolic gesture by this government is what is going to empower us. This government has yet to demonstrate how this proposed voice will deliver practical outcomes and unite, rather than drive a wedge further between, Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australia. And no, prime minister, we donâ€™t need another handout, as you have described the Uluru statement to be. No, we Indigenous Australians have not come to agreement on this statement, as you have also claimed. It would be far more dignifying if we were recognised and respected as individuals in our own right who are not simply defined by our racial heritage but by the content of our character.

Price noted the 47th parliament contained 11 Indigenous representatives, arguing that a voice to parliament amounted to asking â€œthe Australian people to disregard our elected voices and vote yes to apply a constitutionally enshrined advisory body without any detail of what that might in fact entailâ€.

Stephen Bates on LGBTQ+ representation

The Greens MP for Brisbane, Stephen Bates, wore a rainbow ibis brooch and spoke about the importance of LGBTQ+ representation.

Bates paused several times to compose himself as he spoke about his years as a closeted teenager.

Bates said:

I spent much of my teenage years knowing I was gay and doing everything I could to hide it. I told myself I would force myself to get married to a woman, have kids and live in the suburbs. Because that is what I had to do. I was lucky enough to have a very supportive family to come out to but I spent years hiding myself because I could not see anyone in my world that was openly gay. I made a promise to myself once I came out. That if I ever found myself in a public role that I would be open and proud of who I am â€“ hence the rainbow gear. That I would BE that person that I never saw growing up because if I can even help one person out there then this life will have all been worth it.

I was lucky enough during the campaign to have received an email from a mother who told me that after receiving a letter from me in her mailbox â€“ that just happened to mention my partner Scottâ€™s name â€“ her 14-year-old son wanted to donate some of his pocket money to our campaign. When she asked him why, he said he had read the letter and wanted me to win. If you cannot see it, you cannot be it. It is not enough to wave a rainbow flag when it is politically convenient, our community deserves tangible legislation that protects us from discrimination, and empowers us to be who we are.â€

results.webTitle: Australian wholesale energy prices in June quarter tripled from last year, market operator says

fields.headline: Australian wholesale energy prices in June quarter tripled from last year, market operator says
fields.trailText: Aemo executive says need for renewables is â€˜urgentâ€™ as failing coal-fired power plants and global gas costs cause prices to surge
fields.body:
Wholesale electricity and gas prices tripled in Australiaâ€™s main grid in the June quarter compared with a year ago, as failing coal-fired power plants and soaring global gas costs combined to create â€œunprecedentedâ€ market disruptions, the Australian Energy Market Operator said.

Aemoâ€™s quarterly market dynamics report found average spot prices for electricity in the national electricity market, which serves eastern Australia, averaged $264 per megawatt-hour across the quarter. Thatâ€™s more than double the previous high of $130 in the first quarter of 2019 amid droughts and heatwaves, and a little more than three times the average price in the June quarter of 2021, which was $85.

Gas prices averaged $28.40 per gigajoule in east coast markets, up 246% on 12 months ago, and almost triple the previous record of $10.74/GJ set in the September quarter last year.

Violette Mouchaileh, executive general manager at Aemo, blamed the price surge on high global prices for fossil fuels, outages at coal-fired power plants, supply issues, and the deepest cold snap to start a winter â€œin decadesâ€.

â€œWhatâ€™s clear is the urgent need to build out renewable energy with diversified firming generation â€“ like batteries, hydro and gas â€“ and transmission investment to provide homes and businesses with low-cost, reliable energy,â€ Mouchaileh said.

Related: Energy regulators had their hands full keeping the lights on this week â€“ but the next crisis might not be far off | Peter Hannam

The price rises may have been higher if not for the imposition of price caps during several weeks in the quarter, and the first suspension of trading in the national electricity market since its creation in 1998.

The spike in prices has already partly been passed on to households and consumers through their retail bills, but more imposts are to come.

The activation of a payment system to reward companies for reducing energy demand â€“ known as the Reliability and Emergency Reserve Trader â€“ cost about $86m. Compensation costs for losses incurred after authorities ordered power generators back into the market and during the market suspension in June â€œcannot yet be estimated as claims are still being received and assessed,â€ Aemo said.

Another measure of the struggle to meet demand during the quarter was the record number of so-called â€œlack of reserveâ€ conditions declared by Aemo. These rose to 406 separate events â€“ or more than four on average a day â€“ during the three-month period, compared with 36 in the first quarter of this year and 73 in the June quarter of 2021.

Renewable energy continued to expand its share of the market. Output from grid-scale solar and wind rose by 664MW, or 21%, from a year earlier, Aemo said.

Including rooftop solar panels, clean energy supplied 31.8% of the power in the national electricity market, up 3.7 percentage points on the same quarter a year ago.

Output from black coal plants in Queensland and NSW, on the other hand, continued to shrink, dropping 4.8 percentage points to make up 43% of power supplies. Production from Victoriaâ€™s brown coal power stations eased back 0.9 percentage points to make up 15.6% of supply.

Outages caused by failures at black and brown coal plants or because of Covid-related maintenance delays peaked at a record 4.6 gigawatts of capacity in June.

â€œOutages, bidding changes and fuel supply constraints saw black coal generationâ€™s average quarterly output down by 947MW or 8.5% from [the June quarter of 2021] to its lowest June quarter on record,â€ Aemo said.

Related: Victoria demands Aemo maintain minimum gas storage levels as supplies dwindle

Interestingly, an abundance of water actually constrained the amount of hydro power that might otherwise have been generated. â€œDespite very high rainfall, hydro output was only up by 171 MW on average [to an 9.4% share of the market], as some generators in NSW were constrained by water release restrictions,â€ Aemo said.

The reliance on high-cost gas to compensate for coalâ€™s absence â€“ as well as periods of low solar or wind generation â€“ was the main reason for the jump in wholesale prices.

During the quarter, an extra 10 petajoules of gas were used to generate electricity compared with the April-June period of 2021. Overall gas demand, though, edged up only 2 PJ, or 0.5%, as industrial and household users balked at the higher cost and a processing LNG plant outage in Gladstone, Queensland, cut exports.

The strains on the electricity market came even though operational demand only grew 0.6% from a year earlier. The problems were short-term with the cold spell in late May and into early June driving half-hourly demand in Queensland to a record of 8255 MW. In Victoria, the state saw demand reach 8158MW, the highest during the June quarter since 2011.

  • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

Power prices across the states varied in part according to their reliance on black coal. Queensland saw average wholesale electricity prices soar to a record $323/MWh.

Of note, Victoria â€“ where curbs had to be introduced to ensure supplies â€“ was a bigger net exporter of the fuel to other regions thanks to a 20% increase in gas production.

â€œCoupled with production decreases at Moomba [in] South Australia and in Queensland, this saw Victorian gas supply to other states reach its highest level since Q4 2017,â€ Aemo said.

Instead of net flows of 4PJ of gas from Queensland southwards as registered in the June quarter last year, a net 3PJ headed from Victoria northwards in the June quarter just passed.

While future prices show some pullback, electricity prices for 2023 were averaging $168/MWh by the end of the June. Thatâ€™s almost four times higher than the market was expecting in the second quarter of 2021 and well up from the $94 projected at the end of March.

results.webTitle: A perilous adventure on a suburban ice skating rink ends with a helping hand and a wooden whale | Jennifer Wong

fields.headline: A perilous adventure on a suburban ice skating rink ends with a helping hand and a wooden whale
fields.trailText: Life is uncertain enough. So why did I add the twin hazards of a slippery surface and metal-bladed shoes to the mix?
fields.body:
â€œItâ€™s very nice holding your hands,â€ I said to a man Iâ€™d just met.

When you learn to ice skate at your local shopping centreâ€™s outdoor pop-up skate rink, apparently it unlocks a part of your brain that says embarrassing things.

Gabe, the man who owned the hands, is usually an ice hockey goalie, but today, heâ€™s the safety marshall at Winter Wonderlandâ€™s small rink. Heâ€™d offered his hands to help me step on to the rinkâ€™s synthetic, ice-like surface, and I, so startled by the intimacy, couldnâ€™t help but comment on it as if I were suddenly on page 17 of a romance novel.

But this was no time for matters of the heart. I had heavy, rented skates on, and it was time to respect the sanctity of the rented footwearâ€™s purpose: to skate a mile in someone elseâ€™s shoes. Or at least a few metres.

Related: What happened when I stopped hurrying â€“ and discovered the joy of slowing down? | Joan Bakewell

While the ice was not real, my hesitation was. Iâ€™d done no substantial exercise since the start of Covid, and in the spirit of visiting a Winter Wonderland, wore a very large jacket that made me top-heavy and even more unbalanced than usual.

Gabeâ€™s instructions were easy to follow and execute â€¦ until they werenâ€™t.
